ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Would be open to recorded lectures on film techniques and some more in-depth film analysis information.
We also used Google docs to comment on people's work.
Asynchronous commenting on documents.
comments through google drive

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A tremendous amount about script writing and how to construct an effective visual story. The conversations about how to pitch scripts, and industry needs were also really helpful. The beginning of pre-preproduction process was very informative as to what the actual logistics necessary to shooting a short film are.
I learned a lot about developing a screenplay and preparing to make a film!
I learned many basics about writing a script for a short film and also learned fundamentals of storyboarding, budgeting, and otherwise preparing to film.
Learned technical skills required to for the making of a short film. Insight into the process from conception/pitching to writing a script to storyboarding.
Story development, script analysis, creative collaboration
I learned about directing and planning pre-production for a short film.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
A major strength was the quality of feedback given on each assignment, both by students and by the professor. Meeting industry professionals and working writers/directors/producers was also extremely valuable. The way that the assignments built upon each other also felt really helpful and intentional. 

I do think that the structure of the class could be improved a bit though. The four hour time frame is really challenging to do on Zoom, and often by the end of the session, everybody had gone quiet and weren't really giving meaningful feedback anymore. I think this also sort of allowed certain moments to drag on past the point of feeling productive. 

Would also love a little more a lecture/instructional element. In addition to sharing our work, I'd really like from instruction from Jon about effective writing and filmmaking in examples. Similar to what we were doing with the opening sequences for part of the class.
I loved this class and I think its greatest obstacle was the fact that we had to be online! It's hard to be on zoom for 4 hours but Jon made it the best it could be.

I occasionally found that some of the assignments weren't immediately clear, especially not coming from a film background. I wish that we had more time to discuss the projects in advance and talk through their purpose. I think the course was incredibly strong in nurturing a supportive environment in which students could dive into writing with confidence!

The class was fairly long which made it hard to concentrate for the whole time. It was based on doing feedback for each person. One thing that might have helped some of the people in the class was a bit more context/information about each of the assignments before doing them.
It is sometimes difficult to have a natural conversation over zoom, but being able to give comments through google drive helps with that.

This was a challenging course but also extremely rewarding. It's really whatever you bring to the table. The course is a workshop space that provides a supportive and structured environment in which to map out the creation of a short film.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The first part of this class, when focusing more on the writing elements, felt fairly successful over zoom, but the length of the class was just too long.
moments of asynchronous learning were most successful!
I think this course functioned well virtually, although I wonder if we might have had more opportunity to talk through some basics if we were in a room together.

Screensharing helped so that we could all be on the same page. But honestly, engagement was very hard in this digital space. There isn't much that can be improved but I was just very aware of my classmates losing steam as the class went on.

Most of the course is workshopping each other's stories, but I liked the little lessons we had throughout the semester (where we would watch a scene and then talk about it). It really helped ground me in that week's learning objectives. Hopefully this can be incorporated more in the future.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Its a really great introduction to short film making for anyone who is interested in creating their own work.
I encountered this course as a YSD student because of the pandemic so I entered it from a unique circumstance but I would love for future YSD students to have the chance to take it!
I would! Especially  to students interesting in filmmaking, who want to dive in.

Yes, I would definitely recommend for any student that is interested in film and the process of filmmaking/writing/directing. It is all practical which is amazing. You work towards the making of a film so it feels very real and tangible.
I would highly recommend this course to anybody interested in visual storytelling. It is a lot of work, but it pays off.
yes! If you want to make a short fiction film, this is the class to take.
